docs.lead_paragraph: From April to June, people in Virginia's Blue Cross and Blue Shield plan filled 33,722 prescriptions for Celebrex and Vioxx, 27 percent fewer than in the same months last year. At the same time, the insurance company reported a sharp increase in the use of lower-cost generic drugs prescribed for the same purpose, treating arthritis and acute pain.

headline.main: Virginia Blue Cross Plan Leads Shift to Lower-Cost Drugs

docs.abstract: Virginia Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Trigon, leads in efforts to promote generic drugs by continually reminding doctors and patients of savings; Trigon, which requires doctors to get authorization for prescribing Celebrex or Vioxx, assigns 'value ratings' to more than 2,000 drugs and analyzes each doctor's prescriptions every three months (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The programs Frank Furstenberg advocates (Op-Ed, Aug. 13) to support successful marriages among low-income families -- ''child care subsidies, paid parental leaves, cheaper health insurance'' -- are essential but incomplete.

headline.main: If We Truly Value the Family . . .

docs.lead_paragraph: TATZ STUDIO, on the eighth-floor mezzanine of Carnegie Hall, doesn't look or feel like the usual physical therapy center, which is antiseptic, painted in earth tones and decorated in a style that might be called institutional Buddhist. Shmuel Tatz's office has a briny, Old World feel. There's often a slight but unmistakable smell of sweat, which tells you that here the flesh is pressed and serious work is done. Ungainly piles of equipment sit in all three rooms. The lights are dim, the carpeting a bleak gray. The ''waiting area'' is a line of cheap nonergonomic chairs stacked against a wall covered with autographed photos of Peter Jennings, Kathleen Turner, Lou Reed and other celebrity clients.
docs.abstract: Profile of and interview with Shmuel Tatz, 55-year-old Lithuanian Jew who, using variety of therapy techniques including ultrasound, electrical stimulation, magnets, yoga, shiatsu, Swedish massage and laying on of hands, 'tunes' bodies, including those of celebrities, at office in Carnegie Hall; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Bush Addresses Discord About Possible War in Iraq President Bush said he was listening carefully to a group of Republicans -- including Henry A. Kissinger and Brent Scowcroft -- who are warning him against going to war with Iraq, but that he would still make up his own mind based on information tightly held within his administration. A1 Statements by Chancellor Gerhard Schröder that ruled out German participation in an American-led war on Iraq angered American officials. The comments reflect general European doubts about the urgency and wisdom of an attack. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Decade After Health Care Crisis, Soaring Costs Bring New Strains'' (front page, Aug. 11): Insurers, doctors, hospitals, politicians, employers and consumers are blamed for our broken health care system. But there are other players: lawyers whose malpractice lawsuits have sent premiums sky-high and pharmaceutical companies that make enormous profits from drug treatment innovations.
docs.abstract: Kathaleen Grant letter on role of malpractice lawyers and pharmaceutical industry in driving up cost of health care in US (Aug 14 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 11 front-page article about the factors that have contributed to the explosion of spending for health care didn't mention the impact of end-of-life medical care. Too often, extremely ill and dying patients are subjected to multiple interventions and prolonged stays in the intensive-care unit without a realistic chance of long-term survival. More than one-quarter of Medicare dollars are spent in the last year of life.

headline.main: The Rising Cost of Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Todd A Borus letter, commenting on August 11 article on soaring costs of health care, says it failed to mention end-of-life medical care as contributing factor

docs.lead_paragraph: The 10 actors who take turns in ''Embracing Freedom,'' the play performed before visitors to Ellis Island, try their hardest to portray the oppression and poverty overseas that drove millions of immigrants to the United States. But these actors have their own complaints about oppression and poverty, although those of a different order. With the hope of improving their working conditions and how management treats them, they decided to try to join a union, and yesterday the Actors' Equity Association announced that the Ellis Island actors had voted, 7 to 1, to unionize. Two of the 10 votes were challenged and not counted.

headline.main: Actors in Ellis Island Show Vote, 7 to 1, to Join Union

docs.abstract: Ten actors who take turns in Embracing Freedom, play performed before visitors to Ellis Island, vote, 7 to 1, to join Actors' Equity Assn; two of 10 votes are challenged and not counted; actors say several managers with Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, which runs museum, fought unionization (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Health care costs will continue to rise (front page, Aug. 11) as long as people depend on the health care system to keep them healthy, instead of using it as backup when a healthy lifestyle is not enough to keep them well. They will rise as long as fast food is a significant part of our diet.

headline.main: The Rising Cost of Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 11 front-page article about soaring health care costs didn't mention the president's initiative to expand community health centers. The initiative, begun this year, increases federal financing for community health centers by $124 million a year for five years. Its aim is to establish 1,200 new clinics and provide care to six million new patients.

headline.main: The Rising Cost of Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly half a million Long Island residents rely on emergency rooms for their primary medical care, according to a report to be issued Thursday by the Long Island Coalition for a National Health Plan. Experts say the findings mirror the problem of inadequate health coverage nationwide, but are surprising because Long Island is generally affluent.

headline.main: Affluence Aside, Many on L.I. Lack Health Coverage, Report Says

docs.abstract: Long Island Coalition for a National Health Plan report finds nearly half million Long Island residents rely on emergency rooms for primary medical care; says most of uninsured residents are employed, but their employers do not provide coverage and they are unable to afford it on their own; says 16 percent of island's population has unmet health care needs, and roughly half of those people are immigrants who speak English as second language; Suffolk County Department of Health Services Comr Dr Claire Bradley comments; photo (M)
